dozens injured when an express train derailed in north India on Saturday, an official said.\n\nEmergency workers were pulling people out of mangled, up-ended carriages and rushing the wounded to hospital after five coaches derailed early on Saturday evening.\n\n\"Ten people have died and dozens have been injured. Most of the injured have been taken to the hospital,\" said P S Mishra, chief medical officer for the area, by phone.\n\nPolice said the casualties were being rushed to hospital, but they were unable to give numbers.\n\n\"There are certainly casualties but right now the focus is on evacuation,\" senior police officer Jitender Kumar told AFP by phone from the accident site.\n\n\"We are shifting everyone to the hospital. We are trying to take out those trapped inside the coaches.\" Photographs from the scene in the north Indian state of Uttar Pradesh showed people climbing onto up-ended carriages to try to pull passengers out.\n\nThe accident is the latest disaster to hit India's most populous state. It comes just a week after dozens of children died at a hospital that had run out of oxygen there.\n\nIndia's railway network is still the main form of long-distance travel in the vast country, but it is poorly funded and deadly accidents often occur.\n\nLess than a year ago 146 people died in a similar disaster in Uttar Pradesh. A 2012 government report said almost 15,000 people were killed every year on India's railways and described the loss of life as an annual \"massacre\".\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi's government has pledged to invest $US137 billion ($222 billion) over five years to modernise the crumbling railways, making them safer, faster and more efficient.", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "16:07:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T16:07:00Z"}

"At least 10 people were killed on Saturday and 150 injured when a train came off the tracks in India's northern state of Uttar Pradesh, the chief medical officer in Muzaffarnagar, where the crash happened, told Reuters, quoted by The Gulf Today.\n\nA police official earlier said 20 people had been injured but did not mention any people killed.\n\nPolice said the casualties were being rushed to hospital, but they were unable to give numbers or say whether any had died.\n\nOne media report said 15-20 people had been injured and there were fears of fatalities.\n\n\"There are certainly "storyUri": "eng-3374348", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "At least 23 people were killed and dozens injured after an express train derailed in north India Saturday, officials said, as rescuers clambered across mangled carriages to pull passengers from the wreckage.\n\nEmergency workers and crowds of local people rushed to the site where 14 coaches derailed near Muzaffarnagar district in Uttar Pradesh state, some 130 kilometres (80 miles) from New Delhi, the latest deadly disaster on the country's creaking rail network.\n\n\"Twenty-three people have died and 64 others are injured in the accident. Rescue and relief operations are continuing,\" G S Priyadarshi, Muzaffarnagar district magistrate, said.\n\nA police officer at the accident spot said 50 people had been taken to hospital.\n\nPhotographs and television footage showed twisted and upended coaches lying sideways as hundreds of people try to pull the passengers out.\n\n\"We are trying to take out the trapped people from the coaches,\" senior police officer Jitender Kumar said.\n\nAnother official said metal cutters and cranes were being used to reach inside the damaged coaches as the federal government rushed dozens of rescuers with specialised equipment and sniffer dogs to the spot.\n\n\"Scores of people have been safely evacuated from the coaches. Some dead bodies have also been recovered,\" fire and emergency officer Naresh Kumar said.\n\nThe train had left eastern Puri city on Thursday evening and was scheduled to arrive in northern Hindu holy city of Haridwar on Sunday.\n\nThe accident is the latest disaster to hit India's most populous state. It comes just a week after dozens of children died at a hospital that had run out of oxygen there.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi in a tweet expressed sympathies with the families of those killed and assured all possible assistance.\n\nIndia's railway network is still the main form of long-distance travel in the vast country, but it is poorly funded and deadly accidents often occur.\n\nLess than a year ago 146 people died in a similar disaster in Uttar Pradesh after 14 carriages of a passenger train came off the tracks.\n\nMore than 2,000 passengers were on the train when it flipped off the rails that left over 150 injured.\n\nIn January nearly 40 people were killed when eight coaches and the engine of a passenger train derailed in the forest area of southern Andra Pradesh.\n\nA 2012 government report said almost 15,000 people were killed every year on India's railways and described the loss of life as an annual \"massacre\".\n\nModi's government has pledged to invest $137 billion over five years to modernise the crumbling railways, making them safer, faster and more efficient.\n\nHis government has signed numerous deals with private companies to upgrade the network.\n\nJapan has agreed to provide $12 billion in soft loans to build India's first bullet train, with Modi and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe expected to lay its foundation in September.", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "19:19:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T19:19:00Z"}

"storyUri": "eng-3374348", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "At least 23 people were killed and dozens injured after an express train derailed in north India Saturday, officials said, as rescuers clambered across mangled carriages to pull passengers from the wreckage.\n\nEmergency workers and crowds of local people rushed to the site where 14 coaches derailed near Muzaffarnagar district in Uttar Pradesh state, some 130 kilometres (80 miles) from New Delhi, the latest deadly disaster on the country's creaking rail network.\n\n\"Twenty-three people have died and 64 others are injured in the accident. Rescue and relief operations are continuing,\" G S Priyadarshi, Muzaffarnagar district magistrate, told AFP.\n\nA police officer at the accident spot said 50 people had been taken to hospital.\n\nPhotographs and television footage showed twisted and upended coaches lying sideways as hundreds of people try to pull the passengers out.\n\n\"We are trying to take out the trapped people from the coaches,\" senior police officer Jitender Kumar told AFP.\n\nAnother official said metal cutters and cranes were being used to reach inside the damaged coaches as the federal government rushed dozens of rescuers with specialised equipment and sniffer dogs to the spot.\n\n\"Scores of people have been safely evacuated from the coaches. It comes just a week after dozens of children died at a hospital that had run out of oxygen there.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi in a tweet expressed sympathies with the families of those killed and assured all possible assistance.\n\nIndia's railway network is still the main form of long-distance travel in the vast country, but it is poorly funded and deadly accidents often occur.\n\nLess than a year ago 146 people died in a similar disaster in Uttar Pradesh after 14 carriages of a passenger train came off the tracks.\n\nMore than 2,000 passengers were on the train when it flipped off the rails that left over 150 injured.\n\nIn January nearly 40 people were killed when eight coaches and the engine of a passenger train derailed in the forest area of southern Andra Pradesh.\n\nA 2012 government report said almost 15,000 people were killed every year on India's railways and described the loss of life as an annual \"massacre\".\n\nModi's government has pledged to invest $137 billion over five years to modernise the crumbling railways, making them safer, faster and more efficient.\n\nHis government has signed numerous deals with private companies to upgrade the network.\n\nJapan has agreed to provide $12 billion in soft loans to build India's first bullet train, with Modi and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe expected to lay its foundation in September.", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "18:37:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T18:37:00Z"}

1}], "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214", "title": "Mail Online"}, "lang": "eng", "date": "2017-08-19", "title": "At least 23 dead, dozens hurt as train derails in India", "storyUri": "eng-3374348", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "Local residents were searching for survivors after an express train derailed Saturday near the town of Khatauli in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh\n\nAt least 23 people were killed and dozens injured after an express train derailed in north India Saturday, officials said, as rescuers clambered across mangled carriages to pull passengers from the wreckage.\n\nEmergency workers and crowds of local people rushed to the site where 14 coaches derailed near Muzaffarnagar district in Uttar Pradesh state, some 130 kilometres (80 miles) from New Delhi, the latest deadly disaster on the country's creaking rail network.\n\n\"Twenty-three people have died and 64 others are injured in the accident. Rescue and relief operations are continuing,\" G S Priyadarshi, Muzaffarnagar district magistrate, told AFP.\n\nA police officer at the accident spot said 50 people had been taken to hospital.\n\nPhotographs and television footage showed twisted and upended coaches lying sideways as hundreds of people try to pull the passengers out.\n\n\"We are trying to take out the trapped people from the coaches,\" senior police officer Jitender Kumar told AFP.\n\nAnother official said metal cutters and cranes were being used to reach inside the damaged coaches as the federal government rushed dozens of rescuers with specialised equipment and sniffer dogs to the spot.\n\n\"Scores of people have been safely evacuated from the coaches. Some dead bodies have also been recovered,\" fire and emergency officer Naresh Kumar told AFP.\n\nThe train had left eastern Puri city on Thursday evening and was scheduled to arrive in northern Hindu holy city of Haridwar on Sunday.\n\nThe accident is the latest disaster to hit India's most populous state. It comes just a week after dozens of children died at a hospital that had run out of oxygen there.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi in a tweet expressed sympathies with the families of those killed and assured all possible assistance.\n\nIndia's railway network is still the main form of long-distance travel in the vast country, but it is poorly funded and deadly accidents often occur.\n\nLess than a year ago 146 people died in a similar disaster in Uttar Pradesh after 14 carriages of a passenger train came off the tracks.\n\nMore than 2,000 passengers were on the train when it flipped off the rails that left over 150 injured.\n\nIn January nearly 40 people were killed when eight coaches and the engine of a passenger train derailed in the forest area of southern Andra Pradesh.\n\nA 2012 government report said almost 15,000 people were killed every year on India's railways and described the loss of life as an annual \"massacre\".\n\nModi's government has pledged to invest $137 billion over five years to modernise the crumbling railways, making them safer, faster and more efficient.\n\nHis government has signed numerous deals with private companies to upgrade the network.\n\nJapan has agreed to provide $12 billion in soft loans to build India's first bullet train, with Modi and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe expected to lay its foundation in September.", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "18:32:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T18:32:00Z"}

"title": "Utkal Express derailment: 23 dead, 40 injured as 14 coaches go off tracks in Muzaffarnagar", "storyUri": "eng-3374117", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "textEnd": 4209, "date": "2017-08-19", "freq": 2, "textStart": 4197}], "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "Muzaffarnagar: At least 23 people were killed and 40 injured in a major derailment when 14 coaches of the Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar in Uttarakhand went off the tracks with one of the coaches mounting on another near Khatauli in Uttar Pradesh on Saturday evening.\n\nMore casualties are feared as a number of passengers are said to be trapped in the derailed coaches. With nightfall adding to difficulties, the railways were engaged in a grim battle for rescuing those trapped by deploying heavy gas cutters and other equipment to break open into the coaches.\n\n\"Twenty three people have died, and 40 are injured,\" the Uttar Pradesh Director General of Police office said in a release.\n\nThe accident occurred around 5.45 pm when 14 coaches of the Puri-Haridwar Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar derailed in Khatauli in the Meerut-Saharanpur Division. The impact of the accident was so severe that one of the coaches could be seen mounted on another while another coach had crashed into a building along the tracks.\n\nFile image of the derailed coaches of Utkal Express. PTI\n\nRailway spokesperson Anil Saxena said that 14 of the coaches had derailed, while the state police chief's press release said eight coaches had derailed.\n\nPolice and railway officials said they were keeping all options open when asked whether if there could be a terror angle to the accident.\n\nThe railways and the police summoned all equipment including heavy lift cranes and gas cutters to access the affected coaches and cut through them to bring passengers to safety.\n\nThe National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) also rushed forces to join the rescue operation.\n\nA team of the ATS of the state police has been rushed to the accident site, an official told IANS. The team headed by DSP Anoop Singh will probe any terror angle into the rail accident. NDRF teams have also been rushed to the accident site.\n\nChief Minister Yogi Adityanath spoke to principal secretary (Home) Arvind Kumar and the Muzaffarnagar district magistrate (DM) and directed them to ensure prompt rescue and relief operations at Khatauli.\n\nTwo dozen people, many women and children have been admitted to nearby medical facilities for treatment. The train had left Puri at 9 pm on Friday night and was to terminate at Haridwar at 9 pm on Saturday night.\n\nRailway officials said a medical train was on the way and that trains on the route have been diverted through Shamli.\n\nAdditional Superintendent of Police, Muzaffarnagar, Ajay Kumar told IANS that police teams were trying to rescue as many passengers trapped in the coaches as possible.\n\nRailways minister Suresh Prabhu announced an ex-gratia of Rs 3.5 lakh each to the kin of those who lost their lives and Rs 50,000 each for those seriously injured. He also announced Rs 25,000 for passengers with minor injuries.\n\nPrabhu said he was personally monitoring the situation and a probe has been ordered.\n\n\"I am personally monitoring situation. Have instructed senior officers to reach site immediately and ensure speedy rescue and relief operations,\" Prabhu said in series of tweets.\n\n\"Have ordered an inquiry into the unfortunate accident to ascertain the cause. Strict action will be taken against any lapse,\" he said.\n\nThe minister said that medical vans have been rushed to the site. \"All efforts are being taken to ensure speedy relief and rescue operations,\" he said.\n\n\"I have instructed Chairman Railway Board, Member Traffic to oversee rescue and relief operations,\" he said, adding that he has also instructed the General Manager, other senior officials to ensure all possible help to the people.\n\nThe minister said that he was in close touch with Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath, state government officials, district administration to coordinate the rescue and relief operations.\n\nUttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath said that rescue operation has been taken up on a war footing, with Railways and the state government working together.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi, Congress president Sonia Gandhi and party vice president Rahul Gandhi condoled the deaths and expressed sympathies for the families of those who lost their lives.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 19, 2017 09:55 pm | Updated Date: Aug 19, 2017 09:56 pm\n\nTags :#Ajay kumar#Chief minister yogi adityanath#Khatauli#Muzaffarnagar#National disaster response force (ndrf)#Newstracker#Train accident#Utkal express derailment#Uttar pradesh", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "16:30:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T16:30:00Z"}

Most of the injured have been taken to the hospital,\" said P. S. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saharanpur_division", "id": "1440914", "score": 3}], "source": {"uri": "indiatoday.intoday.in", "id": "930", "title": "IndiaToday.in"}, "lang": "eng", "date": "2017-08-19", "title": "Utkal Express derailment: 23 killed, terror angle to be probed; Top updates", "storyUri": "eng-3374117", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "At least 23 people were killed and at least 40 injured in a major derailment when 14 coaches of the Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar in Uttarakhand went off the tracks with one of the coaches mounting on another near Khatauli in Uttar Pradesh on Saturday evening.\n\nMore casualties are feared as a number of passengers are said to have been trapped in the derailed coaches.\n\nUnion Minister and Muzaffarnagar MP Sanjay Balyan, who reached the spot, claimed nearly 60 people were injured. The state police however put the dead at 23 and injured at 40.\n\nHERE IS WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW\"Twenty three people have died, and 40 are injured,\" the office of the Director General of Police office said in a revised release. The earlier release it issued had put the number of injured at 400.With nightfall adding to difficulties, the railways were engaged in a grim battle for rescuing those trapped by deploying heavy gas cutters and other equipments to break open into the coaches.The accident occurred around 5.45 p.m. when 14 coaches of the Puri-Haridwar Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar derailed in Khatauli in Meerut-Saharanpur Division. The impact of the accident was so severe that one of the coaches could be seen mounted on another while another coach had crashed into the Chowdhary Tilakram Inter College along the tracks.Railway spokesperson Anil Saxena said that 14 of the coaches had derailed, while the state police chief's press release said eight coaches had derailed. Police and railway officials said they were keeping all options open when asked whether there could be a terror angle in the accident.The railways and police summoned all equipments including heavy lift cranes and gas cutters to access the affected coaches and cut through them to bring passengers to safety.The National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) also rushed forces to join the rescue operation. Its chief Sanjay Kumar said 20 bodies have been recovered so far.A team of the ATS of the state police has been rushed to the accident site, an official said. The team headed by DSP Anoop Singh will probe any terror angle into the rail accident.Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath directed Principal Secretary, Home, Arvind Kumar and the Muzaffarnagar District Magistrate to ensure prompt rescue and relief operations at Khatauli.The CM also deputed two ministers - Satish Mahana and Suresh Rana - to rush to the accident site to oversee the rescue and relief operations. He also announced an ex-gratia of Rs 2 lakh each for the dead, Rs 50,000 to this injured.Two dozen people, many women and children have been admitted to nearby medical facilities for treatment. The train had left Puri at 9 p.m. on Friday night and was to terminate at Haridwar at 9 p.m. Saturday night.Railway officials said a medical train was on way and that trains on the route have been diverted through Shamli.Additional Superintendent of Police, Muzaffarnagar, Ajay Kumar said that police teams were trying to rescue as many passengers trapped in the coaches as possible.Railways Minister Suresh Prabhu announced an ex-gratia of Rs 3.5 lakh each to the kin of those who lost their lives and Rs 50,000 each for those seriously injured. He also announced Rs 25,000 for passengers with minor injuries.He said he was personally monitoring the situation and a probe has been ordered. \"I am personally monitoring situation. Have instructed senior officers to reach site immediately and ensure speedy rescue and relief operations,\" Prabhu said in series of tweets.\"Have ordered an inquiry into the unfortunate accident to ascertain the cause. Strict action will be taken against any lapse,\" he said. The Minister said that medical vans have been rushed to the site. All efforts are being taken to ensure speedy relief and rescue operations, he said.\"I have instructed Chairman Railway Board, Member Traffic to oversee rescue and relief operations,\" he said, adding that he has also instructed the General Manager, other senior officials to ensure all possible help to the people.The Minister said that he was in close touch with the Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister and state government officials, district administration to coordinate rescue and relief operationsAdityanath said that rescue operation has been taken up on a war footing with railways and the state government working together.President Ram Nath Kovind, Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Congress President Sonia Gandhi and party Vice President Rahul Gandhi have condoled the deaths and expressed sympathies for the families of those who lost their lives.Congress spokesperson Randeep Singh Surjewala took a dig at the Modi government over rail safety, saying that 259 passengers have lost their lives in 27 rail accidents in the last three years. \"When will government wake up?\" he asked.\n\nAlso Read:\n\nUtkal Express derailment: 23 dead, over 100 injured; rescue operations underway\n\nWATCH | Uttar Pradesh: Five coaches of Puri-Utkal Express derail near Muzaffarnagar", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "18:48:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T18:48:00Z"}

"storyUri": "eng-3374348", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "At least 23 people were killed and dozens injured after an express train derailed in north India Saturday, officials said, as rescuers clambered across mangled carriages to pull passengers from the wreckage.\n\nEmergency workers and crowds of local people rushed to the site where 14 coaches derailed near Muzaffarnagar district in Uttar Pradesh state, some 130 kilometres (80 miles) from New Delhi, the latest deadly disaster on the country's creaking rail network.\n\n\"Twenty-three people have died and 64 others are injured in the accident. Rescue and relief operations are continuing,\" G S Priyadarshi, Muzaffarnagar district magistrate, told AFP.\n\nA police officer at the accident spot said 50 people had been taken to hospital.\n\nPhotographs and television footage showed twisted and upended coaches lying sideways as hundreds of people try to pull the passengers out.\n\n\"We are trying to take out the trapped people from the coaches,\" senior police officer Jitender Kumar told AFP.\n\nAnother official said metal cutters and cranes were being used to reach inside the damaged coaches as the federal government rushed dozens of rescuers with specialised equipment and sniffer dogs to the spot.\n\n\"Scores of people have been safely evacuated from the coaches. Some dead bodies have also been recovered,\" fire and emergency officer Naresh Kumar told AFP.\n\nThe train had left eastern Puri city on Thursday evening and was scheduled to arrive in northern Hindu holy city of Haridwar on Sunday.\n\nThe accident is the latest disaster to hit India's most populous state. It comes just a week after dozens of children died at a hospital that had run out of oxygen there.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi in a tweet expressed sympathies with the families of those killed and assured all possible assistance.\n\nIndia's railway network is still the main form of long-distance travel in the vast country, but it is poorly funded and deadly accidents often occur.\n\nLess than a year ago 146 people died in a similar disaster in Uttar Pradesh after 14 carriages of a passenger train came off the tracks.\n\nMore than 2,000 passengers were on the train when it flipped off the rails that left over 150 injured.\n\nIn January nearly 40 people were killed when eight coaches and the engine of a passenger train derailed in the forest area of southern Andra Pradesh.\n\nA 2012 government report said almost 15,000 people were killed every year on India's railways and described the loss of life as an annual \"massacre\".\n\nModi's government has pledged to invest $137 billion over five years to modernise the crumbling railways, making them safer, faster and more efficient.\n\nHis government has signed numerous deals with private companies to upgrade the network.\n\nJapan has agreed to provide $12 billion in soft loans to build India's first bullet train, with Modi and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe expected to lay its foundation in September.", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "18:17:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T18:17:00Z"}

false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "NEW DELHI: In a major train accident, at least 5 passengers have been died and 34 injured after six coaches of 18477 Puri Haridwar Kalinga Utkal Express derailed today near Muzaffarnagar, Uttar Pradesh.\n\nAccording to news reports, the train derailed near Khatauli, Muzaffarnagar at around 5:50 pm. The train runs between Haridwar and Puri.\n\nInitial visuals of the incident suggests that the casualties may rise as several coaches appeared mangled over one another.\n\nThere has been no official confirmation and the reason behind the accident is still not clear.\n\nThe rescue operations are under way. NDRF teams have been mobilised for rescue operation. Injured have been rushed to a local hospital.\n\n\"I am personally monitoring situation.Hv instructed senior officers to reach site immediately and ensure speedy rescue and relief operations,\" Rail minister Suresh Prabhu said on Twitter.\n\n\"Medical vans have been rushed to the site.All efforts being taken to ensure speedy relief and rescue operations. train derailed in northern India Saturday.\n\nAt least five railcars went off the tracks, according to Railways spokesman Anil Saxena, leaving emergency workers and private citizens to pull people out of mangled, upended carriages.\n\n\"Ten people have died and dozens have been injured. Most of the injured have been taken to the hospital,\" said P. S. Mishra, chief medical officer for the area, by phone.\n\nRead more: Train disaster turns focus on India's shoddy railways\n\nPolice said the casualties were being rushed to hospital, but they were unable to give numbers.\n\n\"There are certainly casualties but right now the focus is on evacuation,\" senior police officer Jitender Kumar said from the accident site.\n\n\"We are shifting everyone to the hospital. We are trying to take out those trapped inside the coaches.\"\n\nSecond tragedy in a week\n\nThe derailment occurred in the north Indian state of Uttar Pradesh and is the second tragedy to hit the state in the past week. Dozens of children died in a hospital there that had run out of oxygen.\n\nThe national authorities have sent disaster teams to help.\n\n\"We have mobilized all our resources to provide the best relief and rescue operations at this time,\" Saxena said on Indian television.\n\nIndia's railway network is the main form of long-distance travel in the vast country, but it is notoriously unsafe due to being under funded.\n\nIn the past year 146 people died in a similar disaster in Uttar Pradesh.\n\nA government report in 2012 said almost 15,000 people were killed every year on India's railways. "2017-08-19", "body": "Following the derailment of six coaches of the Puri-Haridwar-Kalinga Utkal Express which took place near Khatauli railway station in Muzaffarnagar, Uttar Pradesh, the Indian Railways informed that around 15-20 people have been injured and that an alternate arrangement is being made for stranded passengers.\n\n\"We don't know the exact figures at the moment, but as per the local people present over there, we have got the information that around 15-20 people have been injured,\" Chief Public Relations Officer (CPRO) of the Northern Railways, Neeraj Sharma told ANI.\n\n\"We are arranging passenger trains and buses for ones willing to travel further,\" he added.\n\nSharma said that right now the priority of the Indian Railway is to provide relief to the one injured.\n\n\"Muzaffarnagar's District Magistrate is reaching the site soon. Additional Director-General of Meerut has also left for the accident site. Railway offices have reached the spot. Senior officers of Indian Railways are also rushing to the spot from Delhi. The injured are being shifted to nearby hospital,\" he said.\n\nHe said that rescue operations have been started and the locals of the area are helping a lot.\n\n\"As soon as the train crossed the Khatauli railway station, six to seven coaches of the train derailed. The first seven coaches of the train next to engine are fine, these coaches were after that,\" she said.\n\nAnil Saxena, Director-general and Public Relation Officer of the Indian Railway said that train derailed near the advanced signal station ahead of the Khatauli railway station.\n\n\"As per the initial information, this incident took place at around 5: 50 pm in the evening. This incident took place at the Northern Railway Delhi division,\" he told ANI.\n\n\"We have not yet received proper information in this matter. We are focusing on relief and rescue operations,\" Saxena said.\n\nMeanwhile, nine Uttar Pradesh Provincial Armed Constabulary (PAC) companies, a team of National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) and Anti-Terrorism Squad (ATS) have been rushed to the spot.\n\nFollowing the derailment of at least six coaches of the Puri-Haridwar-Kalinga Utkal Express in Muzaffarnagar on Saturday, Union Railway Minister Suresh Prabhu has assured that he is personally monitoring the situation and has ordered enquiry on the same.\n\nPrabhu took to Twitter to share information on the same and posted, \"Have ordered inquiry into the unfortunate accident to ascertain the cause. Strict action will be taken against any lapse\"\n\n\"I am personally monitoring situation. Hv instructed senior officers to reach site immediately and ensure speedy rescue and relief operations.\"\n\nHe also informed, \"In close touch with @CMOfficeUP , State Government officials,district administration to coordinate rescue and relief operations.\"\n\nUttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath also took to Twitter to express his grief over the incident and said that the victims will be given proper treatment and orders for rescue and relief operations have been passed.\n\nFormer Uttar Pradesh chief minister Akhilesh Yadav too took to Twitter to share his empathy with the families of the victims.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "15:43:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T15:43:00Z"}

high-speed Utkal Express on Saturday jumped the rails, with one of them crashing into a house adjacent to the track near Khatauli this evening, claiming at least 23 lives and leaving a large number of passengers injured.\n\nThe accident occurred around 5.45pm near Khatauli town in Muzaffarnagar and left 23 people dead and over 60 injured, the Uttar Pradesh Police said. Khatauli is around 40 km from Muzaffarnagar.\n\nRailway ministry officials in Delhi, however, put the number of dead at 12. The train was coming from Puri in Odisha and going to Haridwar in Uttarakhand, normally a journey of about 36 hours.\n\nREAD ALSO: Utkal Express train crash - What we know so far\n\nPAC, ATS and NDRF teams have been rushed to the spot. Heavyweight cranes and gas cutters were being used and locals were seen helping out those engaged in rescue work\n\nMuzaffarnagar authorities have set up a control room to assist families of those affected.\n\nThe numbers are: 0131-2436918, 0131-2436103 and 0131- 2436564.\n\nExtremely pained by the derailment of the Utkal Express in Muzaffarnagar. My thoughts are with the families of the deceased: PM -- PMO India (@PMOIndia)\n\n1503153535000\n\nRailways Ministry & UP Government are doing everything possible & providing all assistance required in the wake of the train derailment: PM -- PMO India (@PMOIndia)\n\n1503153608000\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi expressed extreme pain over the derailment and said the railway ministry and the state government were doing everything possible and providing all assistance required.\n\nHe said the situation was being monitored very closely by the railways ministry.\n\n#Muzaffarnagar train derailment: Visuals from the spot. https://t.co/elpWhkIbbx -- ANI UP (@ANINewsUP)\n\n1503150651000\n\nRailway minister Suresh Prabhu has ordered an inquiry into the derailment. Medical vans have also been rushed to the site.\n\n\"All efforts being taken to ensure speedy relief and rescue operations,\" Prabhu said.\n\nThe railway ministry was also in close touch with the Uttar Pradesh government to coordinate rescue and relief operations.\n\nIn Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh ADG (Law and Order) Anand Kumar said that top priority was being accorded to ensure prompt rescue and relief work.\n\nMeanwhile, Saxena said, \"Initially, we thought that it was only 4-5 coaches, now we have ascertained that 14 coaches have derailed. As of now our focus is on rescue and not on finding reasons for the accident.\"\n\nSince darkness was impeding rescue operations, he said the power department officials had been directed to ensure that there was no shortage of electricity.\n\nKumar also said IMA chapters in Meerut zone have been alerted and asked to ensure adequate and prompt medical care to the injured.\n\nUnfortunate incident, we are in constant touch with the Rail Ministry: UP CM Yogi Adityanath on #Muzaffarnagar trai... https://t.co/ConpCi3MSJ -- ANI UP (@ANINewsUP)\n\n1503153181000\n\nUttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath enquired about the accident and directed officials to take all possible action, an official spokesperson said.\n\nAdityanath has directed two of his ministers - Suresh Rana and Satish Mahana - to reach the site to expedite rescue and relief operations.\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "17:25:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T17:25:00Z"}

"Muzaffarnagar train derailment: 15-20 injured, teams of PAC, ATS dispatched", "storyUri": "eng-3374117", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "textEnd": 15, "date": "2017-08-19", "imp": true, "textStart": 9}], "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "[India], Aug 19 (ANI): Following the derailment of six coaches of the Puri-Haridwar-Kalinga Utkal Express which took place near Khatauli railway station in Muzaffarnagar, Uttar Pradesh, the Indian Railways informed that around 15-20 people have been injured and that an alternate arrangement is being made for stranded passengers.\n\n\"We don't know the exact figures at the moment, but as per the local people present over there, we have got the information that around 15-20 people have been injured,\" Chief Public Relations Officer (CPRO) of the Northern Railways, Neeraj Sharma told ANI.\n\n\"We are arranging passenger trains and buses for ones willing to travel further,\" he added.\n\nSharma said that right now the priority of the Indian Railway is to provide relief to the one injured.\n\n\"Muzaffarnagar's District Magistrate is reaching the site soon. Additional Director-General of Meerut has also left for the accident site. Railway offices have reached the spot. Senior officers of Indian Railways are also rushing to the spot from Delhi. The injured are being shifted to nearby hospital,\" he said.\n\nHe said that rescue operations have been started and the locals of the area are helping a lot.\n\n\"As soon as the train crossed the Khatauli railway station, six to seven coaches of the train derailed. The first seven coaches of the train next to engine are fine, these coaches were after that,\" she said.\n\nAnil Saxena, Director-general and Public Relation Officer of the Indian Railway said that train derailed near the advanced signal station ahead of the Khatauli railway station.\n\n\"As per the initial information, this incident took place at around 5: 50 pm in the evening. This incident took place at the Northern Railway Delhi division,\" he told ANI.\n\n\"We have not yet received proper information in this matter. We are focusing on relief and rescue operations,\" Saxena said.\n\nMeanwhile, nine Uttar Pradesh Provincial Armed Constabulary (PAC) companies, a team of National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) and Anti-Terrorism Squad (ATS) have been rushed to the spot.\n\nFollowing the derailment of at least six coaches of the Puri-Haridwar-Kalinga Utkal Express in Muzaffarnagar on Saturday, Union Railway Minister Suresh Prabhu has assured that he is personally monitoring the situation and has ordered enquiry on the same.\n\nPrabhu took to Twitter to share information on the same and posted, \"Have ordered inquiry into the unfortunate accident to ascertain the cause. Strict action will be taken against any lapse\"\n\n\"I am personally monitoring situation. Hv instructed senior officers to reach site immediately and ensure speedy rescue and relief operations.\"\n\nHe also informed, \"In close touch with @CMOfficeUP , State Government officials,district administration to coordinate rescue and relief operations.\"\n\nUttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath also took to Twitter to express his grief over the incident and said that the victims will be given proper treatment and orders for rescue and relief operations have been passed.\n\nFormer Uttar Pradesh chief minister Akhilesh Yadav too took to Twitter to share his empathy with the families of the victims. (ANI)\n\nSEARCH", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "14:59:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T14:59:00Z"}

"sify.com", "id": "186", "title": "Sify"}, "lang": "eng", "date": "2017-08-19", "title": "13 dead, scores injured as 14 coaches derail in Uttar Pradesh", "storyUri": "eng-3374117", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "Muzaffarnagar: At least 13 people were killed and scores injured in a major derailment when 14 coaches of the Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar in Uttarakhand went off the tracks with one of the coaches mounting on another near Khatauli in Uttar Pradesh on Saturday evening.\n\n\"Thirteen people have died, and 58 injured people have been admitted to hospital,\" Union Minister and Muzaffarnagar MP Sanjeev Balyan told media at the accident spot.\n\nMore casualties are feared as a number of passengers are said to have been trapped in the derailed coaches. With nightfall adding to difficulties, the railways were engaged in a grim battle for rescuing those trapped by deploying heavy gas cutters and other equipments to break open into the coaches.\n\nThe accident occurred around 5.45 PM when 14 coaches of the Puri-Haridwar Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar derailed in Khatauli in Meerut-Saharanpur Division. The impact of the accident was so severe that one of the coaches could be seen mounted on another while another coach had crashed into a building along the tracks.\n\nRailway spokesperson Anil Saxena said that 14 of the coaches had derailed.\n\nPolice and railway officials said they were keeping all options open when asked whether there could be a terror angle in the accident.\n\nThe railways and the police summoned all equipments including heavy lift cranes and gas cutters to access the affected coaches and cut through them to bring passengers to safety.\n\nThe National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) also rushed forces to join the rescue operation.\n\nA team of the ATS of the state police has been rushed to the accident site, an official told IANS. The team headed by DSP Anoop Singh will probe any terror angle into the rail accident. NDRF teams have also been rushed to the accident site.\n\nChief Minister Yogi Adityanath spoke to principal secretary (Home) Arvind Kumar and the Muzaffarnagar district magistrate (DM) and directed them to ensure prompt rescue and relief operations at Khatauli.\n\nTwo dozen people, many women and children have been admitted to nearby medical facilities for treatment. The train had left Puri at 9 PM on Friday night and was to terminate at Haridwar at 9 PM Saturday night.\n\nRailway officials said a medical train was on way and that trains on the route have been diverted through Shamli.\n\nAdditional Superintendent of Police, Muzaffarnagar, Ajay Kumar told IANS that police teams were trying to rescue as many passengers trapped in the coaches as possible.\n\nRailways Minister Suresh Prabhu said he was personally monitoring the situation and a probe has been ordered.\n\n\"I am personally monitoring situation. Have instructed senior officers to reach site immediately and ensure speedy rescue and relief operations,\" Prabhu said in series of tweets.\n\n\"Have ordered an inquiry into the unfortunate accident to ascertain the cause. Strict action will be taken against any lapse,\" he said.\n\nThe Minister said that medical vans have been rushed to the site. All efforts are being taken to ensure speedy relief and rescue operations, he said.\n\n\"I have instructed Chairman Railway Board, Member Traffic to oversee rescue and relief operations,\" he said, adding that he has also instructed the General Manager, other senior officials to ensure all possible help to the people.\n\nThe Minister said that he was in close touch with Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath, state government officials, district administration to coordinate rescue and relief operations\n\nUttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath said that rescue operation has been taken up on a war footing with railways and the state government working together.\n\nSEARCH", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "17:44:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T17:44:00Z"}

"eng-3374117", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "textEnd": 24, "date": "2017-08-19", "imp": true, "textStart": 15}], "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "Muzaffarnagar, August 19 (IANS): At least 23 people were killed and 400 injured in a major derailment when 14 coaches of the Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar in Uttarakhand went off the tracks with one of the coaches mounting on another near Khatauli in Uttar Pradesh on Saturday evening.\n\nMore casualties are feared as a number of passengers are said to have been trapped in the derailed coaches. With nightfall adding to difficulties, the railways were engaged in a grim battle for rescuing those trapped by deploying heavy gas cutters and other equipments to break open into the coaches.\n\n\"Twentythree people have died, and 400 are injured,\" the Uttar Pradesh Director General of Police office said in a release.\n\nThe accident occurred around 5.45 p.m. when 14 coaches of the Puri-Haridwar Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar derailed in Khatauli in Meerut-Saharanpur Division. The impact of the accident was so severe that one of the coaches could be seen mounted on another while another coach had crashed into a building along the tracks.\n\nRailway spokesperson Anil Saxena said that 14 of the coaches had derailed, while the state police chief's press release said eight coaches had derailed.\n\nPolice and railway officials said they were keeping all options open when asked whether there could be a terror angle in the accident.\n\nThe railways and the police summoned all equipments including heavy lift cranes and gas cutters to access the affected coaches and cut through them to bring passengers to safety.\n\nThe National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) also rushed forces to join the rescue operation.\n\nA team of the ATS of the state police has been rushed to the accident site, an official told IANS. The team headed by DSP Anoop Singh will probe any terror angle into the rail accident. NDRF teams have also been rushed to the accident site.\n\nChief Minister Yogi Adityanath spoke to principal secretary (Home) Arvind Kumar and the Muzaffarnagar district magistrate (DM) and directed them to ensure prompt rescue and relief operations at Khatauli.\n\nTwo dozen people, many women and children have been admitted to nearby medical facilities for treatment. The train had left Puri at 9 p.m. on Friday night and was to terminate at Haridwar at 9 p.m. Saturday night.\n\nRailway officials said a medical train was on way and that trains on the route have been diverted through Shamli.\n\nAdditional Superintendent of Police, Muzaffarnagar, Ajay Kumar told IANS that police teams were trying to rescue as many passengers trapped in the coaches as possible.\n\nRailways Minister Suresh Prabhu announced an ex-gratia of Rs 3.5 lakh each to the kin of those who lost their lives and Rs 50,000 each for those seriously injured. He also announced Rs 25,000 for passengers with minor injuries.\n\nPrabhu said he was personally monitoring the situation and a probe has been ordered.\n\n\"I am personally monitoring situation. Have instructed senior officers to reach site immediately and ensure speedy rescue and relief operations,\" Prabhu said in series of tweets.\n\n\"Have ordered an inquiry into the unfortunate accident to ascertain the cause. Strict action will be taken against any lapse,\" he said.\n\nThe Minister said that medical vans have been rushed to the site. All efforts are being taken to ensure speedy relief and rescue operations, he said.\n\n\"I have instructed Chairman Railway Board, Member Traffic to oversee rescue and relief operations,\" he said, adding that he has also instructed the General Manager, other senior officials to ensure all possible help to the people.\n\nThe Minister said that he was in close touch with Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath, state government officials, district administration to coordinate rescue and relief operations\n\nUttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath said that rescue operation has been taken up on a war footing with railways and the state government working together.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi, Congress President Sonia Gandhi and party Vice President Rahul Gandhi have condoled the deaths and expressed sympathies for the families of those who lost their lives.", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "16:38:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T16:38:00Z"}

{"eng": "Ram Nath Kovind"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ram_Nath_Kovind", "id": "1340741", "score": 2}], "source": {"uri": "rediff.com", "id": "542", "title": "Rediff News"}, "lang": "eng", "date": "2017-08-19", "title": "11 killed, 65 injured as 14 coaches of Utkal Express derail in UP", "storyUri": "eng-3374117", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "IMAGE: Coaches of the Puri-Haridwar Utkal Express after it derailed in Khatauli near Muzaffarnagar on Saturday.\n\nAll Photographs: PTI Photo\n\nAt least 11 passengers were killed and over 65 injured when 14 coaches of the Puri-Haridwar Utkal Express derailed in Khatauli near Muzaffarnagar on Saturday evening, officials said.\n\nThe casualty figure might go up.\n\n\"11 dead bodies and 65 injured have been brought to Khatauli hospital,\" UP Principal secretary (Home) Arvind Kumar said.\n\nEarlier, railways spokesperson Anil Saxena put the number of dead at four and the injured at 20.\n\nHowever, UP Additional Director General (Law and Order) Anand Kumar later said that 10 passengers have been killed and 30-40 'seriously injured' in the accident.\n\n\"30 ambulances have reached the spot,\" Kumar said.\n\nThe accident took place around 5.45 pm. Khatauli is around 40 km from Muzaffarnagar. Television visuals show that derailed bogies have crashed into a house.\n\nRailway Minister Suresh Prabhu ordered an inquiry into the derailment. He said he was personally monitoring the situation and strict action will be taken in case of any lapse.\n\nPrabhu later announced ex gratia of Rs 3.5 Lakh for those who lost their lives in the derailment, Rs 50,000 for seriously injured and Rs 25,000 for people with minor injuries.\n\nIn a series of tweets, Prabhu also said that Minister of State Manoj Sinha has rushed to the spot while the chairman of Railway Board and member traffic have been asked to oversee rescue and relief operations.\n\nIMAGE: As many as 14 coaches of the Puri-Haridwar Utkal Express derailed.\n\nTwo National Disaster Response Force teams, comprising 45 personnel each, and two canines have been mobilised to the accident site from their base in Ghaziabad. Medical vans have also been rushed to the site.\n\n'All efforts being taken to ensure speedy relief and rescue operations,' Prabhu said.\n\nThe Railway Ministry was also in close touch with the Uttar Pradesh government to coordinate rescue and relief operations.\n\nIn Lucknow, ADG (Law and Order) Anand Kumar said that top priority was being accorded to ensure prompt rescue and relief work.\n\nHe said teams of Provincial Armed Constabulary and NDRF have been rushed to the spot.\n\nSince darkness was impeding rescue operations, he said the power department officials had been directed to ensure that there was no shortage of electricity.\n\nKumar also said IMA chapters in Meerut zone have been alerted and asked to ensure adequate and prompt medical care to the injured.\n\nKumar said a team of UP Anti-Terrorism Squad was also sent to the spot, though there is no confirmation of the terrorism angle.\n\nSaxena said at this stage, nothing can be said about the cause of the derailment.\n\nUttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath enquired about the accident and directed officials to take all possible action, an official spokesperson said.\n\nAdityanath has directed two of his ministers to reach the site to expedite rescue and relief operations.\n\nAdityanath directed senior ministers Suresh Rana and Satish Mahana to rush to the train accident site.\n\nHe also spoke with the Muzaffarnagar district magistrate and instructed him to ensure all possible relief to affected people, an official spokesperson said.\n\nHospitals have been instructed to provide free treatment to the injured passengers, the spokesperson said.\n\nHe said four NDRF teams were also being rushed there -- three from Ghaziabad and one from Delhi.\n\nBesides, 35 ambulances, bread, butter, 1,000 food packets, additional private and state-run buses were being arranged, he said.\n\nVolunteers were being mobilized from adjoining Meerut, the spokesperson said.\n\nMedical colleges, district hospitals and large number of private hospitals were being prepared to receive patients, he said.\n\nPresident Ram Nath Kovind, Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Congress vice President Rahul Gandhi expressed condolences over the loss of lives in the accident.\n\n'Sad at train derailment in UP; my thoughts are with deceased and their families. Injured are being rescued and provided relief,' President Kovind tweeted.\n\nIMAGE: People gather near the site of accident in Khatauli.\n\nThe PM said the railway ministry and the state government were doing everything possible and providing all assistance required.\n\nHe said the situation was being monitored very closely by the railways ministry.\n\n'Extremely pained by the derailment of the Utkal Express in Muzaffarnagar. My thoughts are with the families of the deceased,' the prime minister tweeted.\n\n'I wish those injured a speedy recovery. The situation is being monitored very closely by the Railway Ministry,' Modi said.\n\nThe railways and the UP government are 'doing everything possible and providing all assistance required in the wake of the train derailment', the PM added.\n\n'Shocked to know about unfortunate accident in Muzaffarnagar. My thoughts with families who lost their loved ones,' Rahul tweeted.\n\nWith ANI inputs.", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "15:58:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T15:58:00Z"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalinga_Utkal_Express", "id": "1440882", "score": 5}], "source": {"uri": "business-standard.com", "id": "405", "title": "Business Standard"}, "lang": "eng", "date": "2017-08-19", "title": " 13 dead, scores injured as 14 coaches derail in Uttar Pradesh (Third Lead) ", "storyUri": "eng-3374117", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "At least 13 people were killed and scores injured in a major derailment when 14 coaches of the Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar in Uttarakhand went off the tracks with one of the coaches mounting on another near Khatauli in Uttar Pradesh on Saturday evening.\n\n\"Thirteen people have died, and 58 injured people have been admitted to hospital,\" Union Minister and Muzaffarnagar MP Sanjeev Balyan told media at the accident spot.\n\nMore casualties are feared as a number of passengers are said to have been trapped in the derailed coaches. With nightfall adding to difficulties, the railways were engaged in a grim battle for rescuing those trapped by deploying heavy gas cutters and other equipments to break open into the coaches.\n\nThe accident occurred around 5.45 p.m. when 14 coaches of the Puri-Haridwar Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar derailed in Khatauli in Meerut-Saharanpur Division. The impact of the accident was so severe that one of the coaches could be seen mounted on another while another coach had crashed into a building along the tracks.\n\nRailway spokesperson Anil Saxena said that 14 of the coaches had derailed.\n\nPolice and railway officials said they were keeping all options open when asked whether there could be a terror angle in the accident.\n\nThe railways and the police summoned all equipments including heavy lift cranes and gas cutters to access the affected coaches and cut through them to bring passengers to safety.\n\nThe National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) also rushed forces to join the rescue operation.\n\nA team of the ATS of the state police has been rushed to the accident site, an official told IANS. The team headed by DSP Anoop Singh will probe any terror angle into the rail accident. NDRF teams have also been rushed to the accident site.\n\nChief Minister Yogi Adityanath spoke to principal secretary (Home) Arvind Kumar and the Muzaffarnagar district magistrate (DM) and directed them to ensure prompt rescue and relief operations at Khatauli.\n\nTwo dozen people, many women and children have been admitted to nearby medical facilities for treatment. The train had left Puri at 9 p.m. on Friday night and was to terminate at Haridwar at 9 p.m. Saturday night.\n\nRailway officials said a medical train was on way and that trains on the route have been diverted through Shamli.\n\nAdditional Superintendent of Police, Muzaffarnagar, Ajay Kumar told IANS that police teams were trying to rescue as many passengers trapped in the coaches as possible.\n\nRailways Minister Suresh Prabhu said he was personally monitoring the situation and a probe has been ordered.\n\n\"I am personally monitoring situation. Have instructed senior officers to reach site immediately and ensure speedy rescue and relief operations,\" Prabhu said in series of tweets.\n\n\"Have ordered an inquiry into the unfortunate accident to ascertain the cause. Strict action will be taken against any lapse,\" he said.\n\nThe Minister said that medical vans have been rushed to the site. All efforts are being taken to ensure speedy relief and rescue operations, he said.\n\n\"I have instructed Chairman Railway Board, Member Traffic to oversee rescue and relief operations,\" he said, adding that he has also instructed the General Manager, other senior officials to ensure all possible help to the people.\n\nThe Minister said that he was in close touch with Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath, state government officials, district administration to coordinate rescue and relief operations\n\nUttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath said that rescue operation has been taken up on a war footing with railways and the state government working together.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "17:21:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T17:21:00Z"}

"business-standard.com", "id": "405", "title": "Business Standard"}, "lang": "eng", "date": "2017-08-19", "title": " 23 dead, 400 injured as 14 coaches derail in Uttar Pradesh (Roundup) ", "storyUri": "eng-3374117", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "At least 23 people were killed and 400 injured in a major derailment when 14 coaches of the Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar in Uttarakhand went off the tracks with one of the coaches mounting on another near Khatauli in Uttar Pradesh on Saturday evening.\n\nMore casualties are feared as a number of passengers are said to have been trapped in the derailed coaches. With nightfall adding to difficulties, the railways were engaged in a grim battle for rescuing those trapped by deploying heavy gas cutters and other equipments to break open into the coaches.\n\n\"Twentythree people have died, and 400 are injured,\" the Uttar Pradesh Director General of Police office said in a release.\n\nThe accident occurred around 5.45 p.m. when 14 coaches of the Puri-Haridwar Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar derailed in Khatauli in Meerut-Saharanpur Division. The impact of the accident was so severe that one of the coaches could be seen mounted on another while another coach had crashed into a building along the tracks.\n\nRailway spokesperson Anil Saxena said that 14 of the coaches had derailed, while the state police chief's press release said eight coaches had derailed.\n\nPolice and railway officials said they were keeping all options open when asked whether there could be a terror angle in the accident.\n\nThe railways and the police summoned all equipments including heavy lift cranes and gas cutters to access the affected coaches and cut through them to bring passengers to safety.\n\nThe National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) also rushed forces to join the rescue operation.\n\nA team of the ATS of the state police has been rushed to the accident site, an official told IANS. The team headed by DSP Anoop Singh will probe any terror angle into the rail accident. NDRF teams have also been rushed to the accident site.\n\nChief Minister Yogi Adityanath spoke to principal secretary (Home) Arvind Kumar and the Muzaffarnagar district magistrate (DM) and directed them to ensure prompt rescue and relief operations at Khatauli.\n\nTwo dozen people, many women and children have been admitted to nearby medical facilities for treatment. The train had left Puri at 9 p.m. on Friday night and was to terminate at Haridwar at 9 p.m. Saturday night.\n\nRailway officials said a medical train was on way and that trains on the route have been diverted through Shamli.\n\nAdditional Superintendent of Police, Muzaffarnagar, Ajay Kumar told IANS that police teams were trying to rescue as many passengers trapped in the coaches as possible.\n\nRailways Minister Suresh Prabhu announced an ex-gratia of Rs 3.5 lakh each to the kin of those who lost their lives and Rs 50,000 each for those seriously injured. He also announced Rs 25,000 for passengers with minor injuries.\n\nPrabhu said he was personally monitoring the situation and a probe has been ordered.\n\n\"I am personally monitoring situation. Have instructed senior officers to reach site immediately and ensure speedy rescue and relief operations,\" Prabhu said in series of tweets.\n\n\"Have ordered an inquiry into the unfortunate accident to ascertain the cause. Strict action will be taken against any lapse,\" he said.\n\nThe Minister said that medical vans have been rushed to the site. All efforts are being taken to ensure speedy relief and rescue operations, he said.\n\n\"I have instructed Chairman Railway Board, Member Traffic to oversee rescue and relief operations,\" he said, adding that he has also instructed the General Manager, other senior officials to ensure all possible help to the people.\n\nThe Minister said that he was in close touch with Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath, state government officials, district administration to coordinate rescue and relief operations\n\nUttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath said that rescue operation has been taken up on a war footing with railways and the state government working together.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi, Congress President Sonia Gandhi and party Vice President Rahul Gandhi have condoled the deaths and expressed sympathies for the families of those who lost their lives.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "17:20:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T17:20:00Z"}

Kalinga Utkal Express derailed in Khatauli near Muzaffarnagar in Uttar Pradesh this afternoon.\n\nThe total number of people killed and injured in the accident that took place around 5:45 pm was yet to be ascertained.\n\nIt is reported that at least 10 people were killed and over 50 were injured in the accident after several coaches of the express derailed .\n\nThe injured have been rushed to local hospital.\n\nLocal district administration, railway officials and NDRF team have rushed to the spot and relief and rescue operations are under way.\n\nA team of Anti Terrorist Squad (ATS) has been sent to the accident site to ascertain if there is a terror link to the derailment.\n\nThe train with number of 18477 had left Puri on Thursday night and was scheduled to reach Haridwar at 9 pm tonight.\n\n\"I am personally monitoring situation.Hv instructed senior officers to reach site immediately and ensure speedy rescue and relief operations,\" Railway Minister Suresh Prabhu tweeted.\n\nRailway department has issued helpline no 9760534054/5101 for emergency contact.\n\nOdisha Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik expressed his concern over the tragic incident and directed the commerce and transport department to work in coordination with the Railway department in rescue operation.\n\n\"Deeply anguished by the loss of lives in Kalinga #Utkal Express in UP. My thoughts and prayers with victims' families and the injured,\" he tweeted.\n\nSpoke to Shri @sureshpprabhu & he has assured all help to the affected passengers. "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "textEnd": 21, "date": "2017-08-19", "imp": true, "textStart": 15}], "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "Muzaffarnagar, Aug 19 (IANS) At least 23 people were killed and 400 injured in a major derailment when 14 coaches of the Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar in Uttarakhand went off the tracks with one of the coaches mounting on another near Khatauli in Uttar Pradesh on Saturday evening.\n\nMore casualties are feared as a number of passengers are said to have been trapped in the derailed coaches. With nightfall adding to difficulties, the railways were engaged in a grim battle for rescuing those trapped by deploying heavy gas cutters and other equipments to break open into the coaches.\n\n\"Twentythree people have died, and 400 are injured,\" the Uttar Pradesh Director General of Police office said in a release.\n\nThe accident occurred around 5.45 p.m. when 14 coaches of the Puri-Haridwar Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar derailed in Khatauli in Meerut-Saharanpur Division. The impact of the accident was so severe that one of the coaches could be seen mounted on another while another coach had crashed into a building along the tracks.\n\nRailway spokesperson Anil Saxena said that 14 of the coaches had derailed, while the state police chief's press release said eight coaches had derailed.\n\nPolice and railway officials said they were keeping all options open when asked whether there could be a terror angle in the accident.\n\nThe railways and the police summoned all equipments including heavy lift cranes and gas cutters to access the affected coaches and cut through them to bring passengers to safety.\n\nThe National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) also rushed forces to join the rescue operation.\n\nA team of the ATS of the state police has been rushed to the accident site, an official told IANS. The team headed by DSP Anoop Singh will probe any terror angle into the rail accident. NDRF teams have also been rushed to the accident site.\n\nChief Minister Yogi Adityanath spoke to principal secretary (Home) Arvind Kumar and the Muzaffarnagar district magistrate (DM) and directed them to ensure prompt rescue and relief operations at Khatauli.\n\nTwo dozen people, many women and children have been admitted to nearby medical facilities for treatment. The train had left Puri at 9 p.m. on Friday night and was to terminate at Haridwar at 9 p.m. Saturday night.\n\nRailway officials said a medical train was on way and that trains on the route have been diverted through Shamli.\n\nAdditional Superintendent of Police, Muzaffarnagar, Ajay Kumar told IANS that police teams were trying to rescue as many passengers trapped in the coaches as possible.\n\nRailways Minister Suresh Prabhu announced an ex-gratia of Rs 3.5 lakh each to the kin of those who lost their lives and Rs 50,000 each for those seriously injured. He also announced Rs 25,000 for passengers with minor injuries.\n\nPrabhu said he was personally monitoring the situation and a probe has been ordered.\n\n\"I am personally monitoring situation. Have instructed senior officers to reach site immediately and ensure speedy rescue and relief operations,\" Prabhu said in series of tweets.\n\n\"Have ordered an inquiry into the unfortunate accident to ascertain the cause. Strict action will be taken against any lapse,\" he said.\n\nThe Minister said that medical vans have been rushed to the site. All efforts are being taken to ensure speedy relief and rescue operations, he said.\n\n\"I have instructed Chairman Railway Board, Member Traffic to oversee rescue and relief operations,\" he said, adding that he has also instructed the General Manager, other senior officials to ensure all possible help to the people.\n\nThe Minister said that he was in close touch with Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath, state government officials, district administration to coordinate rescue and relief operations\n\nUttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath said that rescue operation has been taken up on a war footing with railways and the state government working together.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi, Congress President Sonia Gandhi and party Vice President Rahul Gandhi have condoled the deaths and expressed sympathies for the families of those who lost their lives.\n\n--IANS\n\nmd-bns-aks-ps/rn/vsc\n\nSEARCH", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "17:14:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T17:14:00Z"}

"2017-08-19", "body": "Coaches of the Puri-Haridwar Utkal Express after it derailed in Khatauli near Muzaffarnagar on Saturday. PTI\n\nFour passengers were killed and at least 20 injured when 14 coaches of the Puri-Haridwar Utkal Express derailed in Khatauli near here this evening, officials said.\n\nRailways spokesperson Anil Saxena put the number of dead at four and the injured at 20.\n\nThe accident took place around 5:45 pm. Khatauli is around 40 km from Muzaffarnagar. Television visuals show that derailed bogies have crashed into a house.\n\nRailway Minister Suresh Prabhu ordered an inquiry into the derailment. He said he was personally monitoring the situation and strict action will be taken in case of any lapse.\n\nIn a series of tweets, Prabhu also said that Minister of State Manoj Sinha has rushed to the spot while the Chairman of Railway Board and Member Traffic have been asked to oversee rescue and relief operations.\n\nTwo National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) teams, comprising 45 personnel each, and two canines have been mobilised to the accident site from their base in Ghaziabad.\n\n\"All efforts being taken to ensure speedy relief and rescue operations,\" Prabhu said.\n\nThe Railway Ministry was also in close touch with the Uttar Pradesh government to coordinate rescue and relief operations.\n\nIn Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh ADG (Law and Order) Anand Kumar said that top priority was being accorded to ensure prompt rescue and relief work.\n\nHe said PAC and NDRF teams have been rushed to the spot.\n\nSince darkness was impeding rescue operations, he said the power department officials had been directed to ensure that there was no shortage of electricity.\n\nKumar also said IMA chapters in Meerut zone have been alerted and asked to ensure adequate and prompt medical care to the injured.\n\nUttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath enquired about the accident and directed officials to take all possible action, an official spokesperson said.\n\nAdityanath has directed two of his ministers to reach the site to expedite rescue and relief operations.", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "15:46:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T15:46:00Z"}

"817032", "score": 2}], "source": {"uri": "channelnewsasia.com", "id": "1555", "title": "Channel NewsAsia"}, "lang": "eng", "date": "2017-08-19", "title": "Train derails in India, killing about 20 and injuring scores more", "storyUri": "eng-3374309", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "NEW DELHI/MUMBAI: A train came off the tracks in northern India on Saturday, killing about 20 people and injuring scores more, as carriages slammed into each other, officials said.\n\nRescuers and local people worked into the night searching for survivors in the overturned and mangled carriages, some piled on top of each other. The death toll in the the northern state of Uttar Pradesh was expected to rise, officials said.\n\nAt least eight carriages derailed in the crash close to Muzaffarnagar, about 130 km (80 miles) north of the capital New Delhi, as the train travelled towards the Hindu holy city of Haridwar, police said.\n\nTrain crashes are frequent in India, which has the world's fourth biggest rail network. Poor investment in past decades in the vast network and rising demand means overcrowded trains are running on creaking infrastructure.\n\nSaturday's accident is at least the fourth major passenger train derailment this year and the third in Uttar Pradesh in 2017. A crash in November in Uttar Pradesh killed 150 people.\n\nA senior police officer in the state, Anand Kumar, said close to 20 people had been killed and more than 80 injured.\n\nSanjeev Balyan, a Muzaffarnagar lawmaker, had earlier told Reuters that at least 14 people had been killed.\n\n\"We are struggling to pull out injured, and are waiting for gas cutters to arrive. It's too dark to launch a full fledged search operation, but our teams are trying their best,\" said Ajay Pandey, a senior police officer at the site.\n\nThe national authorities sent disaster teams to help.\n\nIndian Prime Minister Narendra Modi sent a message on Twitter saying he was pained by the derailment of the Utkal Express, offering condolences to families of those killed and wishing a speedy recovery to the injured.\n\nIn June, Reuters reported that a planned US$15 billion safety overhaul of India's rail network was facing delays as the state steel company could not meet demand for new rails.\n\nThe network is in the middle of a US$130 billion, five-year modernisation. The government launched the additional safety overhaul programme in February to tackle a surge in train accidents in the past two years blamed on defective tracks.\n\nA senior official in the Uttar Pradesh government, Arvind Kumar, told the Hindustan Times the train driver had slammed the brakes on after spotting maintenance work on the tracks that was not properly signalled, the newspaper reported.\n\nAnil Saxena, a spokesman for the railways, said it was too early to speculate about the causes of Saturday's crash.\n\n(Additional reporting by Euan Rocha, Rupam Jain and Suvashree Choudhury; Writing by Tommy Wilkes; Editing by Toby Chopra and Edmund Blair)", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "19:54:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T19:54:00Z"}

"storyUri": "eng-3374117", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-19", "body": "At least 23 people were killed and at least 40 injured in a major derailment when 14 coaches of the Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar in Uttarakhand went off the tracks with one of the coaches mounting on another near Khatauli in Uttar Pradesh on Saturday evening.\n\nMore casualties are feared as a number of passengers are said to have been trapped in the derailed coaches. Union Minister and Muzaffarnagar MP Sanjay Balyan, who reached the spot, claimed nearly 60 people were injured.\n\nThe state police however put the dead at 23 and injured at 40.\n\n\"Twentythree people have died, and 40 are injured,\" the office of the Director General of Police office said in a revised release. The earlier release it issued had put the number of injured at 400.\n\nWith nightfall adding to difficulties, the railways were engaged in a grim battle for rescuing those trapped by deploying heavy gas cutters and other equipments to break open into the coaches.\n\nThe accident occurred around 5.45 p.m. when 14 coaches of the Puri-Haridwar Kalinga Utkal Express bound for Haridwar derailed in Khatauli in Meerut-Saharanpur Division. The impact of the accident was so severe that one of the coaches could be seen mounted on another while another coach had crashed into the Chowdhary Tilakram Inter College along the tracks.\n\nRailway spokesperson Anil Saxena said that 14 of the coaches had derailed, while the state police chief's press release said eight coaches had derailed.\n\nPolice and railway officials said they were keeping all options open when asked whether there could be a terror angle in the accident.\n\nThe railways and police summoned all equipments including heavy lift cranes and gas cutters to access the affected coaches and cut through them to bring passengers to safety.\n\nThe National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) also rushed forces to join the rescue operation. Its chief Sanjay Kumar said 20 bodies have been recovered so far.\n\nA team of the ATS of the state police has been rushed to the accident site, an official told IANS. The team headed by DSP Anoop Singh will probe any terror angle into the rail accident.\n\nChief Minister Yogi Adityanath directed Principal Secretary, Home, Arvind Kumar and the Muzaffarnagar District Magistrate to ensure prompt rescue and relief operations at Khatauli. He also deputed two ministers - Satish Mahana and Suresh Rana - to rush to the accident site to oversee the rescue and relief operations.\n\nHe also announced an ex-gratia of Rs 2 lakh each for the dead, Rs 50,000 to this injured.\n\nTwo dozen people, many women and children have been admitted to nearby medical facilities for treatment. The train had left Puri at 9 p.m. on Friday night and was to terminate at Haridwar at 9 p.m. Saturday night.\n\nRailway officials said a medical train was on way and that trains on the route have been diverted through Shamli.\n\nAdditional Superintendent of Police, Muzaffarnagar, Ajay Kumar told IANS that police teams were trying to rescue as many passengers trapped in the coaches as possible.\n\nRailways Minister Suresh Prabhu announced an ex-gratia of Rs 3.5 lakh each to the kin of those who lost their lives and Rs 50,000 each for those seriously injured. He also announced Rs 25,000 for passengers with minor injuries.\n\nHe said he was personally monitoring the situation and a probe has been ordered.\n\n\"I am personally monitoring situation. Have instructed senior officers to reach site immediately and ensure speedy rescue and relief operations,\" Prabhu said in series of tweets.\n\n\"Have ordered an inquiry into the unfortunate accident to ascertain the cause. Strict action will be taken against any lapse,\" he said.\n\nThe Minister said that medical vans have been rushed to the site. All efforts are being taken to ensure speedy relief and rescue operations, he said.\n\n\"I have instructed Chairman Railway Board, Member Traffic to oversee rescue and relief operations,\" he said, adding that he has also instructed the General Manager, other senior officials to ensure all possible help to the people.\n\nThe Minister said that he was in close touch with the Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister and state government officials, district administration to coordinate rescue and relief operations\n\nAdityanath said that rescue operation has been taken up on a war footing with railways and the state government working together.\n\nPresident Ram Nath Kovind, Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Congress President Sonia Gandhi and party Vice President Rahul Gandhi have condoled the deaths and expressed sympathies for the families of those who lost their lives.\n\nCongress spokesperson Randeep Singh Surjewala took a dig at the Modi government over rail safety, saying that 259 passengers have lost their lives in 27 rail accidents in the last three years.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "eventUri": "eng-3374117", "timeCrawl": "18:52:00", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T18:52:00Z"}
